comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: Yay! More bicycles, please! These are Rudge-Whitworth 'path racing' bicycles, with a raised hand on the head-badge! Also note the chrome(nickel?)-plated, sloping fork-crown!! Great picture!! Badge- P.S. The chainwheels might look like this- , although that might be a later development?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Have they been taking horse tranquilizers or why are the veins standing out in their arms like that?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Thanks, Carol. They look as if they mean business. I have doubts as to whether it's the same Tyler Challenge Cup, but Freeman's Aug 27 1895 describes a splendid specimen of the silversmith's art donated by Tyler & Son "the world-famed boot people"

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: Snazzy suit on the man at left.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Other red herrings: a Tyler Cup for GAA in Wexford, another Tyler Cup for something horsey  again in Wexford, and another horsey Tyler Cup but in Armagh. All 1890s.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Great photo Carol, I've seen this before in the catalogue. The Tyler's mentioned is very likely the same company that had a shop in Waterford and are still in business I believe. There is a nice photo of one of their premises in the collection catalogue.nli.ie/Record/P_WP_0784

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Blackpoolbeach notes that there are no brakes on the bikes.  These were "fixed wheel" bikes and the braking was done by using the pedals!

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] I ride 'fixed wheel' on the road, but I've got both front & rear brakes- don't believe anyone who says they can stop quickly from speed, using just leg-power alone!! It's just for the track (or 'path', as these guys would say).

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach/] I think these bikes would have had the 'standard' number of spokes (in the UK & Eire, at least), at that time, i.e. 40 at the rear,32 at the front. Superseded much later by 36 + 36, and now much smaller numbers, quite often; even down to 3 or 4 carbon fibre spokes, or solid 'dish' rims!
The bikes above may also have top-tubes (crossbars!), which slope downwards towards the front, which was common for racing bicycles at the time? (Re-introduced as 'Low-Profile'
in the 1970s, but with a smaller front wheel.)
'Taches, are of course, coming back into fashion for the discerning Gentleman Cyclist!!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abaraphobia] I know what you mean, try too hard and the wheel locks and you end up with some nice abrasions to show for your foolhardiness!

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/] Could you also show the previous photo in your archive, of this group, P_WP_1944, but with two bicycles featured?

comment.author: 57241905@N03
comment._content: Nice photo.   I am no longer Paddy Fitz Photo's. It is now P.G.M Photography(BATH)

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: I like the men holding up the bicycles, holding on for dear life... The kickstand had not yet been invented, or I suppose they wanted the cyclists in an "action pose"...

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
No brakes on them bicycles.
Presumably they tried to reverse-peddle in an attempt to slow the bike down and considering how fast they might be going....!
